column4: you need to get that module loaded by either: A) Modprobing, or B) rebooting
If your a good little Linux user, you modprobe ;-)
welp, try rebooting :-)

well you have two choices... google for the bttv driver source and compile and install, or reinstall ubuntu again. If your ubuntu install is new anyhow, that might just be faster.. althoguh you "wont learn as much"
when I installed the kernal again why did it say something about grub ?
grub needs to know where the new kernel is in order to load it on boot
so theres no chance it kept the old one and booted the old one but added the new one on the list ?
well you were really just re-installing the same kernel, but youcan verify with uname -r
so theres no chance it kept the old one and booted the old one but added the new one on the list ?
I mean http://tldp.org/HOWTO/BTTV/hw.html
so how do I compile this bt module ?
so how do I compile this bttv module ?
well, you'd actually be better off using the module in the kernel package...
I think this is the command that killed rmmod bttv
not really sure why the reinstall didnt replace the modules with a fresh copy
if I can remove the module with rmmod bttv there should be a easy way to reinstall it.
its part of the kernel-modules package
should I see if I can use the recovery ubuntu kernal option ?
you can try booting to that, then doing the reinstall of the kernel modules package again
whats the command to reinstall the kernel again ?
sudo apt-get install --reinstall linux-image-2.6.20-15-generic
